title: 113_hr4831
content: The Act may be cited as the "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014". It includes provisions for federal matching payments for state new manufacturing jobs training tax credits. The Secretary of the Treasury will make quarterly payments to eligible community colleges based on new manufacturing job withholding matches. Eligible trainees will receive a match from participating manufacturing employers. Eligible community colleges are public higher education institutions. The term "eligible community college" refers to a public higher education institution that primarily awards 2-year associate's degrees acceptable for credit towards a bachelor's degree, located in a state with a new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program, and participates in the program through a qualifying contract. The program established by a State government allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for training. State income taxes withheld by the employer for the trainee will be remitted to the community college for education provided. The contract between an eligible community college and a manufacturing employer in the State allows State income taxes withheld for the trainee to be remitted to the college for education. The contract between an eligible community college and a manufacturing employer in the State ensures that qualified training is provided to individuals designated by the employer, with no tuition or fees charged. The employer must hire these individuals for full-time employment at a job site within the State, and they will be paid by the employer. The employer must hire individuals for full-time employment at a job site within the State, paying them a wage that is at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage or the amount specified by the State program. The employer will remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of the individual to the community college for training costs. The employer must hire individuals for full-time employment at a job site within the State, paying them a wage that is at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage or the amount specified by the State program. The employer will remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of the individual to the community college for training costs. Qualified training refers to education or training that provides necessary skills for the job the individual will be employed in. The contract must specify the entire cost of training, including equipment and materials, which should be reasonable by market standards. The State program requires individuals to have education, skills, licenses, certificates, or credentials aligned with industry standards for new manufacturing jobs. The State program for new manufacturing jobs training tax credit requires eligible trainees to be hired for new jobs, not jobs of recalled workers or replacements within the past year. The new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program requires eligible trainees to be hired for new jobs within the employer's business, resulting in a net increase in employment. Only U.S. employees at job sites in the United States are considered for this program. The new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows employers to work with local workforce investment boards to hire and train eligible individuals for new jobs in the United States. All persons treated as a single employer under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code are considered a single employer for this program. Eligible trainees must be hired for new jobs within the employer's business to qualify for the tax credit. The term "eligible trainee" refers to an individual who received qualified training from an eligible community college under a state new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program and is employed full-time by the employer who was part of the training contract. The trainee must work at a job site in the same state as the community college, earn a wage that meets specific requirements, and be in a job that fulfills the new job requirement. The term "eligible manufacturing employer" refers to a person who employs individuals in manufacturing, with facilities in the US, and primary business classified in sectors 31, 32, or 33 of the NAICS. Appropriation of necessary funds from the Treasury for the implementation of the section, remission of State income tax withholdings for eligible manufacturing employers to eligible community colleges, and tax treatment of payments for eligible trainees. Tax Treatment of Payments With Respect to Eligible Trainee: Payments withheld for State income tax and payments made under subsection (a) for eligible trainees are not considered income for tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amounts withheld for State income taxes are treated as payments made by the eligible trainee for tax deduction purposes.
